title: BftProcessorExecutor-QBFT-0 | ERROR | AbstractBlockProcessor | failed persisting block org.hyperledger.besu.plugin.services.exception.StorageException: org.rocksdb.RocksDBException: Busy

labels.name: non mainnet (private networks)
labels.description: not related to mainnet features - covers privacy, permissioning, IBFT2, QBFT

body:
### Description
I have a private blockchain where all the validator nodes crashed and stopped processing blocks. They all seemed to have the error(s) attached below. This is extremely similar to [https://github.com/hyperledger/besu/issues/5441] which happened on besu version 23.4.0. However, the solution says it was an underlying hardware issue which I feel is unlikely as this happened to my nodes running on AWS. Any further discussion on this issue would be greatly appreciated, thank you!

### Steps to Reproduce
I am unsure how to reproduce this error as it seems to be an error with rocksdb. Using v23.1.2, ubuntu 22.04 running on t2.large aws instances.

**Expected behavior:** 
Expected the system to fix the error and start processing blocks again. 

**Actual behavior:** 
Error continues and seems to cause additional errors for the blockchain that cause the blockchain to stop processing blocks.

**Frequency:** 
This has only happened once so far on October 12th. 

### Versions 
Software version: besu v23.1.2
Java version: 17.0.8.1
OS Name & Version: Ubuntu 22.04.2 LTS
Kernel Version: x86_64
Cloud VM, type, size: AWS t2-large

### Logs
```

### Additional Information 
Besu setup info 

```
besu --data-path=<path> \
    --miner-enabled \
    --miner-coinbase=0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000 \
    --min-gas-price=0 \
    --genesis-file=<path> \
    --rpc-http-enabled \
    --rpc-http-api=ETH,NET,QBFT,WEB3,ADMIN,TXPOOL \
    --host-allowlist="*" \
    --rpc-http-cors-origins="all" \
    --discovery-enabled=false \
    --Xdns-enabled=true \
    --rpc-http-port=23000 \
    --rpc-http-host=$IP \
    --p2p-port=54000 \
    --p2p-host=$IP \
    --p2p-interface=$IP \
    --sync-mode=FULL \
    --metrics-enabled \
    --static-nodes-file=<path>  > /tmp/besu-$(date '+%s').out 2>&1
```

what is your storage layer configuration on this aws instance?  Besu requires reasonably fast storage, something like attached nvme or EBS volume with IOPS configured in relation to the size of the storage the chain is using.  

`fio` tool can give you concrete numbers on IO performance.  Install that and run this test from the data partition you are using:

`sudo fio --randrepeat=1 --ioengine=libaio --direct=1 --gtod_reduce=1 --name=test --filename=test --bs=4k --iodepth=64 --size=4G --readwrite=randrw --rwmixread=75`

FYI, for our dev-test nodes we have machines spec'd fairly lean, and their IO perf on this test is:

```
sudo fio --randrepeat=1 --ioengine=libaio --direct=1 --gtod_reduce=1 --name=test --filename=test --bs=4k --iodepth=64 --size=4G --readwrite=randrw --rwmixread=75

@siladu @jframe @matthew1001 - are you aware of any qbft-specific concurrency that might cause rocksdb busy errors during block processing and/or reorgs?  The logs seem to show either a reorg or out-of-order block processing:

```
2023-10-12 00:13:21.014+00:00 | BftProcessorExecutor-QBFT-0 | INFO  | MainnetBlockValidator | Invalid block <block number> (0x5...): Optional[org.rocksdb.RocksDBException: Busy], caused by org.hyperledger.besu.plugin.services.exception.StorageException: org.rocksdb.RocksDBException: Busy
2023-10-12 00:13:21.014+00:00 | BftProcessorExecutor-QBFT-0 | INFO  | ProposalPayloadValidator | Invalid Proposal Payload: block did not pass validation. Reason Optional[org.rocksdb.RocksDBException: Busy]
